questions.question_text: Which three components are required to deploy a stretched cluster in a VMware Cloud Foundation environment? (Choose three.)

choices.F: DHCP on the host overlay network
choices.D: One witness host per vSAN stretched cluster
choices.B: vSAN, host overlay and vMotion network stretched across both sites
choices.E: vSAN, host overlay and vMotion network per data site
choices.A: DHCP on the NSX Edge overlay network

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DEF
As explained in my previous comment

Selected Answer: BDE
B: A stretched cluster requires the vSAN, host overlay, and vMotion networks to be stretched across both sites to ensure seamless communication and data synchronization between the two sites.

D: A witness host is required for a vSAN stretched cluster to act as a tiebreaker in case of a site partition or failure. Only one witness host is needed per vSAN stretched cluster, not per site.

E: Each data site must have its own vSAN, host overlay, and vMotion networks to ensure proper operation and redundancy within the site.

DEF are correct.

vSAN stretched clusters in VMware Cloud Foundation have the following requirements:
• A vSAN Enterprise license.
• The Management domain cluster must be stretched before any workload clusters are stretched.
• Networking in both data sites that meets the requirements:
The vSphere vMotion, vSAN, Host Overlay Transport and Management networks must be stretched (L2) or routed (L3) between data sites.
• DHCP must be available on the Host Overlay Transport in each data site.
• The NSX Edge Uplink and NSX Edge Overlay Transport VLANs must be stretched L2 across both data sites.
• A third Witness site for the witness host or appliance that meets the requirements

Taken from Lesson Book VMware Cloud Foundation: Deploy, Configure, Manage [V5.0]

Selected Answer: BDF
BDF are correct. Below are the requirements:
The vSphere vMotion, vSAN, Host Overlay Transport and Management networks must

The round-trip time (RTT) between data sites must be ≤ 5 milliseconds.
The NSX Edge Uplink and NSX Edge Overlay Transport VLANs must be stretched L2 
across both data sites.

questions.question_text: Which two steps must be performed to create a vSphere with Tanzu namespace? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
cd is correct

I think is AC

As people say here DE are tasks post creation. So the only useful answers are A and C. The "A" is because a prerequisite is "Configure a cluster with vSphere with Tanzu" the question doesn't have more information but if there is not a vSphere Cluster we have to deploy it. However, it is just an assumption. So, Answer C is the only one involved in the creation process

The key word here is "CREATE". In order to create it you need: 
• Select a cluster enabled for vSphere with Tanzu. [A]
• Provide a DNS-compliant name for the namespace. [C]

Before you can "USE" it you need: 
Use the vSphere Client to configure permissions and storage before a namespace can be used:
• Assign permissions to users to either edit or view the namespace. [D]
• Assign a VM storage policy to the namespace.
• Define resource limits. [E]

So A & C are correct.

Selected Answer: AC
A&C. It's a pre-req to have the vSphere Cluster.

Selected Answer: AC
And if it is A and C???
You need a vSphere Cluster.

Selected Answer: DE
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/vmware-vsphere-with-tanzu/GUID-1544C9FE-0B23-434E-B823-C59EFC2F7309.html

vSphere with Tanzu workloads, including vSphere Pods, VMs, and Tanzu Kubernetes clusters, are deployed to a vSphere Namespace. You define a vSphere Namespace on a Supervisor Cluster and configure it with resource quota and user permissions. Depending on the DevOps needs and workloads they plan to run, you might also assign storage policies, VM classes, and content libraries for fetching the latest Tanzu Kubernetes releases and VM images.
